title: nicola-sturgeon-lockdown-update-covid-rules-set-ease
story: Nicola Sturgeon confirmed that most of Scotland will enter Level  lockdown next week.People in Scotland will be able to hugged loved ones again from Monday ndash subject to restrictions ndash an emotional Nicola Sturgeon has said as she confirmed further lockdown easing.These changes will include meeting up to six people from three households socialising indoorsrestaurants, cafeacutes, pubs and bars openingindoors until :cinemas, theatres, comedy clubs, amusement arcades and bingo halls reopening andquarantine-free international travel.It comes after the Covid- alert level in the UK was downgraded from Level  to Level  after a "consistent"fall in cases, hospital admissions and deaths.The four chief medical officers of the UK put it downto the success of the vaccination programme and social distancing restrictions.Heres what you need to know:Scotland to enter Level The First Minister confirmed that the majority of Scotland will move to Level  lockdown from May .Moray will stay in Level and the Scottish Islands will move to Level  from Monday.These changes will include, but are not limited to, being able to meet inside a home, drinking alcohol inside a pub or restaurant, the reintroduction of adult contact sports and meeting eight peoplefrom eight households outdoors.Household changesThe maximum number of people who can meet indoors socially ina homeis six people which can be from three households, including for overnight stays.Hugs are back!Nicola Sturgeon has confirmed that hugs will be allowed indoors in Scotland.The First Minister said: "From Monday,you are meeting friends and family, within the permitted limits of course, either indoors in a private dwelling or in your garden, our guidance will say that it is no longer necessary to maintain physical distance."Which means - and I actually feel a bit emotional as I say this - that from Monday, as long as you stay within permitted limits, you can hug your loved ones again."I know how desperate we all are for this - and so I donrsquot intend to immediately pour cold water on it - but there are two further points I really need to make."She added: "Close physical contact does still carry risk, I have to be clear about that."Soyou have loved ones who are vulnerable for any reason, please still be careful. And limit the overall number of people that you choose to have close physical contact with."Moray decisionNicola Sturgeon confirmed that Moray will not move to Level  and will stay in Level  for a "further period".The decision comes as health authorities in the area are currently dealing with "uncontrolled, sustained community transmission"of Covid-, with current restrictions failing to contain the spread.Latest statistics show Moray had . cases per , people in the seven days to May , signicantly higher than the rate in the rest of Scotland.Travel restrictions willbe brought into Moray and people should only enter there for essential purposes only.Ms Sturgeon said: "In recent days, as you will have seen, Moray has been experiencing a high and increasing number of cases with a small associated increase in hospital admissions."Indeed, public health experts consider that Moray is currently experiencing widespread community transmission."She added: "It is therefore highly probable that Moray will stay at level  for a further period."It is also important that we take precautions to reduce the risk of the transmission of Covid spreading from Moray to other parts of Scotland, as restrictions ease where.""SoMoray does stay in level  - which will be finally decided at the end of the week - we will also reimpose travel restrictions for a hopefully short period.This will mean that travel in and out of Moray will be limited to permitted purposes only."Islands changesMany islands in Scotland will move to Level  due to low case numbers.Nicola Sturgeon said:"For our island communities, the situation is dferent and much more positive."Case numbers have consistently been at very low levels for some time now."Many islands also now have very good vaccination coverage, and lateral flow tests are available for all people travelling to the islands from other parts of Scotland."For those reasons, we have decided that it is possible to ease restrictions more quickly for communities in the Western Isles, Shetland and Orkney for all islands in Highland, except Skye, given its fixed link and for the Inner Hebrides islands in Argyll - including Islay, Jura and Mull."All of these areas will move directly to level  from Monday, rather than to level ."International TravelPeople in Scotland will be able to travel to some foreign destinations without the need to quarantine on their .It will be part of a traffic lights system, similar to that in England, and will come into effect on May .Countries are to be classied as green, amber and red and a review will take place every four weeks.Nicola Sturgeon said: "At the outset, let me be very clear that we still intend to be highly cautious on international travel - given the risk of new iants - but we consider that the situation now allows us to begin a careful move away from blanket restrictions on non-essential travel."From Monday, we will move to a traffic light system, informed by risk assessments prepared by the Joint Biosecurity Centre. These assessments will be based on the state of the pandemic in each country across the world - including the presence of iants of concern."These green countries include:PortugalIsraelSingaporeAustraliaNew ZealandBruneiIcelandGibraltarFalkland IslandsFaroe IslandsSouth Georgia and the Sandwich IslandsSt Helena, Tristan de Cunh and Ascension IslandLatest case numbersThe First Minister was unable to update on the latest Covid numbers due to "IT issues".Nicola Sturgeon said:"I hope that will be resolved soon, and I can assure you that all of todays figures will be published just as quickly as possible."Youll be able to access them when theyre published on the Scottish Government website."

title: galashiels-high-street-update-empty-polish-shop-building
story: THERE has been an update on the future of an empty shop on a Borders high street.Plans were lodged last year to turn the Polish Shop ndash a former grocery store ndash on GalashielsHigh Street into one two-storey house and a flat.At Galashiels Community Council last Wednesday , Rick Kenney said the plans have been re-submitted to Scottish Borders Councilto ldquomeet modern building standards.ldquoItrsquos been closed for a few years now, Mr Kenney said.ldquoIn July they submitted a plan to change it to some homes but keep the same design on the building on the outside.ldquoItrsquos another empty building that wersquore getting back into use.:mph speed limits: Tell us what you think, says Scottish Borders CouncilThere were no adverse comments submitted by the community council.When the initial plans were lodged last year, an SBC planning officer said: ldquoI recognise the loss of the retail use, but also note the building has had non-retail uses in the recent past .ldquoI accept the residential use may be a less vibrant contributor to the town centre, and that there are no other ground floor residential uses fronting the High Street.ldquoHowever, a residential use will, nonetheless, be a positive contributor, and this shop comprises an unremarkable and modest property located at the end of the town centre, well away from the principal activity area of the town.ldquoThere is also a range of uses in this part of town already, including residential uses on upper floors.ldquoA residential use on the ground floor would have a negligible effect on the strength of the town centre overall and the character of this end of the town, and would maintain the mixed use nature of this area.

title: scotland-home-year-inside-katie-spiers-home
story: BEING a lestyle blogger can open a number of doors. For Glasgow-based Kate Spiers, every day her inbox fills with new opportunities. Yet when Scotlandrsquos Home Of The YearTV crew came knocking, she admits it was completely new territory to consider.ldquoI didnrsquot really have TV in my mind, says Spiers, , ldquoit wasnrsquot something I thought I would ever do. Irsquove always been happy with my online job and content creation, but when I went for a meeting with the team, I just loved them ndash they were so passionate about the show, and I just thought lsquookay, letrsquos try it out!rsquoThe popular home show continues to attract a strong following in its third series,Spiers believes demand will be at an all-time high. ldquoI think itrsquos a really great programme to go on after so long in lockdown, she highlights.ldquoWhen everyonersquos been looking at the same four walls for the last year, lots of people have big plans for what theyrsquore going to do with their homes, and for when they can have tradesmen back into the house, so I think watching an interiors show is going to be inspiring for people hellip a welcome bit of voyeurism.Despite the fluctuating restrictions of the pandemic last year, the crew, alongside Spiersrsquos fellow judges interior designer Anna Campbell-Jones and architect Michael Angus, were able to film series three last September.ldquoI would not recommend filming during a pandemic, laughs Spiers. ldquoWe would do Covid tests every couple of days, get temperature checks twice a day ndash we constantly had thermometers hanging out of our mouths.ldquoWe were really lucky we could get out to film, and it was great to see more of Scotland.Originally from New Zealand, Spiers considers herself an honorary Scot since moving here as a child. The content creator has a weighty , followers on Instagram, many of whom were gained over the last year alone. ldquoMy following grew massively during the pandemic, she explains, ldquowhereas it hadnrsquot grown that much in the last couple of years.One of the main reasons for this influx is Spiersrsquos dreamy, aesthetically pleasing interiors.ldquoI would think my niche, or my USP, is probably that I live quite a simple le ndash I view my content as being attainable but slightly aspirational.ldquoMy husband and I live in a three-bedroom tenement flat in the southside of Glasgow ndash itrsquos far from a mansion, but it has period detailing and wersquove done a lot of work to make it our own and inject our personality into it. Itrsquos also a style that is easy to replicate.ldquoIrsquom quite inspired by Southern Calornian style ndash lots of wood and greenery, earthy tones, and textures. I bring a lot of that into my home, I love rattan and a bit of s style. I think Irsquove created quite a colourful home that brings me a lot of joy.So, after being able to add TV presenter to her ever-growing CV, whatrsquos next for Spiers  ldquoWriting is my passion, she emphasises. ldquoI would love to write a book one day, a collection of essays, I think ndash thatrsquos something Irsquove always been leading up to. Although everybody always wants me to do an interiors book!Kate shares her top tips to freshen up your home for springThere is no better time to refresh your home than the start of a new season, and the arrival of spring definitely brings with it a chance to declutter and revive your space. Itrsquos like redecorating but without spending a penny.Bring the outdoors:in Stock up on tulips, daffodils and peonies, and place bouquets around your home ndash on mantelpieces, sideboards, kitchen worktops and coffee tables. Irsquom a big fan ofgreenery in the home too ndash plants like Pothos, Monstera deliciosa and ZZ plants are so easy to take care of and really breathe a bit of le into a room. Irsquom all about the indoor jungle, so go wild with blooms and plants and your home will feel bright and breezy in no time.Consider a lick of paint:With so many fun paint brands launching lately , itrsquos easier than ever to add colour to your le. Opt for a fresh eucalyptus green to revive a bathroom, or pick a played-down pink for warmth. Go wild with it ndash paint a feature wall in your living room or section off a room with a dado rail and paint the lower section a bright shade. Bold colours never go out of style.www.katelavie

title: kelso-high-school-homes-getting-built-former-site
story: WORK has started to build affordable homes on the former site of a Borders high school, according to Eildon Housing.The housing association is working with Kelso-based contractor M  J Ballantyne to create  extra care homes ndash also known as assisted living accommodation ndash at the previous base of Kelso High School.The building of the  homes is outlined as phase one and is expected to take two years.Phase two will then involve a further  homes including two two-bedroom properties with wheelchair access.Eildonrsquos chief executive Nile Istephan said: ldquoOur new strategy focuses on the responses given from the three key groups we consulted our customers, our stakeholders and our people .ldquoThe issues that came out most strongly were that we should continue to provide new high quality, affordable and sustainable homes for our communities and develop and deliver new services to respond to the specic needs of our older population, those living with dementia and groups vulnerable to becoming homeless.According to an Eildon spokesperson, architect Aitken Turnbullrsquos ldquosympathetic design for the Kelso homes includes retaining the ldquoart deco facade of the former school.Kelsorsquosnewly-built high school on Angraflat Road opened to students in .

title: galashiels-academy-full-council-meeting-supports-option-3
story: COUNCILLORS have agreed to take forward plans to build the new Galashiels Academy on the local authoritys preferred site.At a meeting on Thursday , elected members of Scottish Borders Councilwere asked to support Option  of the consultation ndash which includes siting part of the new pound million campus in Scott Park.For months, campaigners have been voicing concernsover building on green space in the town.And the meeting of the full council was told that  negative comments were lodged opposing the proposed site during the informal consultation period.But a report to members stated "there is widespread support amongst the school community and the wider silent majority for the project".At the online meeting, all four Galashielscouncillors spoke passionately for the project.Fantastic facilitiesCouncillor Andy Anderson, of the SNP, said it was a "once in a letime opportunity to create something really special" in the town.He added: "What I would like to see is the community come together on this one."This will provide fantastic education and community facilities and I believe the setting is second to none."We have a fantastic parkland there which we can use. This can be integrated in for community use and we have a fantastic opportunity to integrate the [Gala] Policies, which will be of huge benefit to the community."I am looking forward to seeing this proceed through to the next stages."Very passionate viewsEuan Jardine, of the Conservatives, said: "The term once in a generation is used a lot these days. Some people believe once in a generation can be as little as five years."However, once in a generation is ndash  per cent, in this case ndash  to  years."That means that a young person attending the community campus will, more than likely, see their grandchildren attending the same campus."There has been a lot of community discussion on this project and very passionate viewson both sides of the debate."I am sure everyone involved only wants what they believe to be best for the town."However, I have spoken to many people about this project from both sides of the debate and I have always said that I was open to what the consultation was going to say."Now, after carefully reading the consultation, it states that the preferred way forward from the community is Option . Therefore, I will support this option today."Town has been patientSBC says the website, outlining the range of options for the town, was visited more than , times.And it stated "there does not appear to be any community-based support for Options ,  and ".But despite calls for site Option  to be considered, a report to the council says "the views and suggestions of the opposition group have not changed the overall option appraisal process in terms of the preference for Option ".Councillor Sandy Aitchison, an independent member for Galashiels, said: "As we look forward, we are looking at  or  before we get there and that is a date I look forward to immensely."Without doubt, I support this. Gala has been very patient, in terms of this. We have been talking about a new school for a long time. Im a former pupil of Gala Academy, but not that building thats currently standing there."It was the one at Melrose Road, which is, of course, a blight on the landscape. I think what that does is highlight a problem of building new. What do you do with the old "In this case, with the proposals for building the new Gala Academy on site, we will demolish the old building and clear the site after we have created this wonderful, new facility."Officers thankedHarry Scott, also an independent member for the town, said: "There has been a very informed opposition to the project, but I think uppermost in everybodys mind has to be the educational facility this will provide to the young people."As far as I am concerned, the sports facilities are an aside. Its education that is important."I am happy to support the paper and thank the officers for all the work they have done."During the meeting, convener David Parker spoke in favour of the project shyndash as did Carol Hamilton, the councils executive member for children and young people.The right thing to doMr Parker, an independent member for Leaderdale and Melrose, said: "The council has replaced five of its nine secondary schools in the last  years."Those schools in Duns, Earlston, Eyemouth, Kelso and Jedburgh have brought first-class teaching and learning facilities and they have also developed new and exciting community facilities."Its now the turn of Galashiels and over the next five years, the council has committed to delivering projects in Galashiels, Hawick and Peebles."I hope after today we can go on to talk about Hawick and Peebles and the exciting plans for those towns as well."It would be fantastic , in this letime of the council, we could signal a clear delivery timescale for Selkirk as well ndash completing the nine high school journey."[In Galashiels] there is still work to do in terms of the educational consultation, the planning issues and the future development of the project, but I think today is a milestone in the project and its the right decision."East Berwickshire representative Ms Hamilton, of the Conservatives, added: "As executive member its my duty to ensure we provide the best education for our young people."Offering this modern and up-to-date facility is just the right thing to do in the Scottish Borders."We owe our young people a top-class facility for learning and the community a space for all community activities."

title: melrose-chiefswood-road-one-way-system-summer
story: A BORDERS road is having a one-way system introduced ndash despite "signicant" opposition.Scottish Borders Council has announced that Chiefswood Road, near Melrose, will shut this weekend so the summer-long trial scheme can begin on Monday .Yet the plans were unpopular among Melrose residents when a public consultation was held, with  people being opposed ndash compared with  in favour.The councilrsquos executive member for infrastructure, travel and transport, Gordon Edgar, said: ldquoI must stress that this [one-way] trial will be temporary, and that no permanent decisions have been made.Depending on how the trial goes, the council says, a permanent off-road pathway for walkers and cyclists might eventually be created alongside Chiefswood Road.:Driver lucky to be alive after crash on dangerous Borders road, meeting toldA council spokesperson said: ldquoWhile a signicant percentage of respondents to the consultation would not wish for the trial to take place, the consultation also indicated that  per cent of the respondents would use the shared spaceit were installed.ldquoOn that basis, and following conversations with Melrose Community Council, the council will progress with a temporary trial of the one-way system over the course of the summer to further assess demand.ldquoThe purpose of this trial will be to provide supporting evidence that could be used to support a funding bid for a permanent off-road path running alongside Chiefswood Road.ldquoThe trial will see vehicle access permitted downhill only towards Borders General Hospital and a mph speed limit introduced.ldquoTemporary bollards will be installed for safety reasons to separate vehicles from the dedicated walking and cycling lane.:Full report: Why controversial Galashiels Academy plans were given thumbs upldquoA two-way flow of traffic would be maintained between Fairways and Dingleton Hill and also from the Harleyburn House access to the junction with High Cross Avenue. Diverted vehicles will be redirected for an additional km through Melrose.ldquoThe road will then revert back to a two-way street on or before September .ldquoChiefswood Road will be closed on Saturday and Sundayfor works to be undertaken with the new one-way system commencing on Monday, May .The trial is part of the councilrsquos Spaces for People programme, runs in partnership with Transport Scotland and Sustrans. The project aims to encourage more walking and cycling.The full results of the consultation can be found here.

title: melrose-waverley-castle-hotel-reopen-new-ownership
story: A BORDERS hotel has been rescued from closure and will soon welcome back guests.The Waverley Castle Hotel, near Melrose, faced an uncertain future last year when its owner at the time, Shearings Hotels, went into administration.Now under new ownership, the -bedroom business will reopen on Mondayin line with the relaxation of coronavirusrules.Bespoke Hotelrsquos portfolio managing director Paul FitzGerald said: ldquoGiven the enormous challenges of the last few months, wersquore delighted to bring the Waverley Castle hotel back to market."He added: ldquoItrsquos a lovely property in a delightful location, and we know the initial closure was felt keenly amongst the local community.ldquoBut now, with reopening plans in place, wersquore able to offer not just jobs and wider tourism opportunities, but a hospitality service that people can engage with as restrictions lt.The change in ownership comes after a hotel management agreement with Bespoke Hotels ndash and the Waverley Castle is now part of the lsquoCoast  Country Hotel Collectionrsquo, which consists of former Shearings-owned properties.The Waverley Castle, which is set in five acres of parkland, offers rooms from pound per night for bed and breakfast.It will reopen under general manager James Moutrie, who was in the same role previously. The hotel says it is in the process of recruiting  staff.Bespoke Hotelsrsquo managing director Thomas Greenall said: ldquoCoast  Country Hotel Collection is made up of some prominent local hotels in some wonderful and well-established leisure locations and wersquore thrilled to be able to facilitate their reopeningldquoWe know the initial closures of many of these properties caused a real stir in their local communities last year, so we hope theyrsquoll be keen to embrace their reopening and support the inidual hotels in their endeavours.He added: ldquoWe hope this will be regarded as a very positive move for the area ndash delivering jobs, support for communities and vital trade for suppliers and ancillary businesses.

title: scots-not-enough-information-independence-poll-suggests
story: Nearly six out of  Scots think they do not have enough information to make an informed choice on independence, a poll has suggested.It comes as former Prime Minister Gordon Brown called on the Scottish National Party to ldquoopen the books and hold public hearings in Holyrood and Westminster on the effects of leaving the UK.Overall, fewer than a third of poll respondents felt confident about knowing the effect of independence on issues including the English border, Scotlandrsquos security arrangements, tax, currency, and EU membership.The survey was carried out on behalf of Our Scottish Future, a non-profit organisation set up by Mr Brown in  which says it stands for ldquomiddle Scotland ndash in between ldquohardline nationalism and ldquomuscular unionism.Some , Scots were questioned by Stack Data Strategy between May  and , with responses weighted to census figures on age, gender, education level, and recorded vote in the Scottish Parliamentary elections, the group said.Mr Brown said in a statement: ldquoMiddle Scotlandrsquos support for the SNP and for independence is conditional ndash and they are now asking the SNP for honesty, for openness and for getting the facts on the table.ldquoIt is time for the SNP to open the books.ldquoI believe that it is time for the SNP to agree to hold public hearings on what independence means for everything from the pound to the pension.Respondents were asked: ldquoDo you believe that campaigners for independence have given enough information about what Scotland would be likeit became independentfor you to make a fully informed choice at a future referendum A total of % said ldquoNo, while % said ldquoYes and the remaining % said ldquodonrsquot know.And among those who strongly favour independence, % said they had enough facts, but % said they did not.Mr Brown added: ldquoWhen even a quarter of committed independence supporters agree we donrsquot know enough to make an informed choice on independence, surely the onus is on the SNP to come clean The poll also asked voters to set out their top three priorities.Overall, ldquoNHS catch-up was the most popular, followed by ldquoreduce Covid vaccines then ldquoprotect and generate jobs.ldquoPrepare for a second independence referendum was eighth on the list overall, fth among SNP voters, and third among those who identy as nationalists, figures show.The First Minister, Nicola Sturgeon, has told Prime Minister Boris Johnson that a second vote on Scottish independence should be a ldquomatter of when ndash not , while SNP Westminster leader, Ian Blackford, said earlier this week there is now a ldquofresh democratic commitment to give the Scottish people the right to choose an independent future.SNP MSP George Adam said: ldquoThe SNP won last weekrsquos election by a landslide and there is an unprecedented, -seat, cross-party, pro-indy majority at Holyrood.ldquoThe First Minister was absolutely clear throughout the election campaign, as was the SNP manesto, that her immediate focus was continuing to lead Scotland safely through the pandemic.ldquoBut once the COVID crisis has passed, people in Scotland have the right to choose our own future, and whether to equip our parliament with the powers it needs to drive Scotlandrsquos long-term recovery, not to leave our recovery in the hands of the austerity-driven Tories.ldquoThat means there will be a post-pandemic, independence referendum and, as the First Minister has also repeated time and time again, it will be at that point the SNP bring forward a detailed and comprehensive prospectus for independence ndash as it did in  ndash that addresses all those questions the people of Scotland will quite rightly want answered.ldquoMeanwhile, the people of Scotland might also want to know why Gordon Brown continues to campaign to keep Scotland subjected to a disastrous hard-Brexit Tory Government ndash which this country has emphatically rejected ndash and deny us the immense opportunities of having full powers to use our human and natural resources to build a better Scotland..push,i[r].l*new Dateas,ms[]a.asynca.srcgmgagagagagagagagagagaga, title: Most Scots do not have enough information on independence, poll suggests

title: ministers-urge-cautious-approach-new-freedoms-coronavirus-lockdown-eases
story: Boris Johnson and health experts have urged people to exercise caution when they head to pubs and restaurants as the lockdown eases despite concerns about the spread of an Indian coronavirus iant.Although ministers believe the vaccines will be effective against the highly transmissible Indian iant of concern, there are worries about the impact of its spread on those who have refused to have a jab or not yet been offered one.The Prime Minister urged people to treat the latest easing of restrictions with a ldquoheavy dose of caution while Business Secretary Kwasi Kwarteng warned against excessive drinking for those ing to bars.From today:ndash People in England can meet outdoors in groups of up to , and indoors in groups of six, or two households, with pubs and restaurants able to serve customers inside.ndash Museums, cinemas and other indoor attractions can reopen.ndash The ldquostay in the UK restriction will lt and people will be able to go on holiday to ldquogreen list countries including Portugal without having to quarantine on their , provided they take one post-arrival test.ndash Wales moves to alert level two with the reopening of indoor hospitality and entertainment venues.Covid restrictions ease further today as many parts of Scotland move to level and many islands to level . title: new-covid-19-vaccine-study-pregnant-women-launches
story: The UKrsquos first Covid- vaccine study for pregnant women is set to launch.Around  women will be given the Pfizer BioNTech vaccine or a placebo in the study, which is taking place at  hospital sites in Newcastle, Leeds, London, Oxford, Gillingham, Edinburgh and Southampton.More than , pregnant women have already been vaccinated in the US, mainly with mRNA vaccines including Pfizer BioNTech and Moderna, with no safety concerns.For this reason, the Joint Committee on Vaccination and Immunisationin the UK has said it is preferable for pregnant women in the UK to be offered the Pfizer BioNTech or Moderna vaccines.There is no evidence to suggest other vaccines are unsafe for pregnant women but studies are ongoing.Participants for the new study will be identied via obstetricians and midwives at the hospital sites involved.All women in the study will be given the Covid vaccine at some point, including those initially given a placebo.Dr Chrissie Jones, associate professor in paediatric infectious diseases at the University of Southampton, and chief investigator for the study said: ldquoWhile we have a large amount of real-world data which tells us that itrsquos safe for pregnant women to receive approved Covid- vaccines, the data gathered from a controlled research study like this is important because it will give us more information about the vaccine immune response in pregnant women, including the transfer of maternal antibodies to infants.ldquoAll women taking part in the study will receive two doses of the approved Pfizer BioNTech vaccine, as well as additional monitoring and support from their local research team.Professor Nigel Simpson, consultant obstetrician and gynaecologist at Leeds Teaching Hospital and NIHR specialty lead for reproductive health, said: ldquoCatching Covid- in pregnancy can have serious consequences for mothers and their babies.vw,vw,px, px"The women will be given the Pfizer BioNTech vaccine or a placebo ldquoIn the title: noise-pollution-another-price-pandemic-sleepless-brits
story: Nearly eight in ten Brits are suffering from unwanted noise in their homes, with close to a third saying it is affecting their sleep.New research reveals that % of the UK population have had their sleep affected by unwanted external noise, with three in tenreporting that it stops them opening doors and windows, and a quartersaying it stops them relaxing.And the data from leading sustainable insulation company Rockwool showed a thirdhave noticed more noise since Covid- lockdowns began last year."Noise is a major nuisance, but worse than that it can also seriously affect peoplersquos health and wellbeing, said Gloria Elliott, chief executive of the Noise Abatement Society.ldquoThis data shows that noise is a serious problem, impacting on our quality of le and the enjoyment of our homes.ldquoIn the discussion about how we build back better after the pandemic, noise mustnrsquot be forgotten. We want to see good acoustic design embedded in residential development so homes are built to enhance the lives of people that live there.Indeed, figures suggest the pandemic has led to a massive % increase in noise complaints to local authorities across the country.Itrsquos a challenging brief. Itrsquos complex.The scale is huge, but yoursquore up to it, arenrsquot you If only there was a data-rich, virtual environment where you could explore how @ROCKWOOLUKsolutions can be used across a modern city.Guess what  There is. https:t.co ZnFFPVtRhpic ICrOLpWlEmmdash ROCKWOOL UKApril , The biggest rises came in Birmingham, followed by the London boroughs of Richmond upon Thames and Bexley, which recorded increases of %, % and % respectively when compared with the previous year.The World Health Organisation has previously found that at least one million healthy le years are lost every year in Western Europe as a result of exposure to environmental noise, making it the second largest environmental cause of ill health, after air pollution. Studies have shown that exposure to unwanted noise can contribute to sleep disturbance, hypertension, and an increased risk of diabetes, dementia, stroke and heart disease. ldquoThe pandemic has led to more people working, studying, and spending time in their own homes, said Rockwoolrsquos Managing Director Darryl Matthews.ldquoWith this theyrsquove become more aware of unwanted noise and our results show itrsquos having a detrimental effect on their ability to relax, unwind, or even sleep.ldquoThis is a massive issue currently flying under the radar. With more people now likely to work from home after the pandemic and increasing populations in our towns and cities, noise has the potential to be a critical issue and have a negative impact on peoplersquos physical and mental health.

title: t-signs-deal-combine-media-empire-discovery
story: ATT will combine its massive media operations that include CNN, HBO, TNT and TBS in a  billion dollar deal with Discovery, the owner of lestyle networks including the Food Network and HGTV.Faced with strong competition from streaming services, major broadcast media companies have sought strength through mergers.The deal would create a separate media company with households increasingly abandoning cable and satellite TV, looking instead at Netflix, Amazon Prime Video, Facebook, TikTok and YouTube.vw,vw,px, px"Streaming services like Netflix are fierce competition for traditional media companies In the all-stock deal, ATT will receive  billion dollars in a combination of cash, debt securities, and WarnerMediarsquos retention of certain debt. ATT shareholders will receive stock representing % of the new company and Discovery stockholders will own % of the new company.ATT had pushed into the streaming sector through HBO Max, a direct competitor with Netflix, Apple, Disney and Comcast. Discovery launched a standalone streaming service called Discovery Plus this year.The deal to give up its media business marks a major sht by ATT, which fought hard to push a transaction through in  to buy Time Warner for . billion dollars with the Justice Department trying to block the deal on anti-competitive reasons.The deal is expected to close by the middle of next year..push,i[r].l*new Dateas,ms[]a.asynca.srcgmgagagagagagagagagagaga, title: ATT signs deal to combine media empire with Discovery

title: former-ross-high-pupil-ruari-paton-aiming-scottish-cup-glory
story: Ruari Paton will be hoping to line up for Stranraer todaywhen they make the long journey north to face Brora Rangers, who stunned Hearts in the previous round.The frontman attended the Tranent secondary school after signing for Hibernian as a teenager and making the move from Dublin.Many had expected Stranraer to be travelling to Tynecastle this weekend but Brora caused one of the biggest shocks in the competitionrsquos history when they won - last Tuesday.Paton was part of the Stranraer team taking on Brechin City at the same time and said that his reaction was much the same as football fans up and down the country when he heard the result.He said: ldquoI would not like to take anything away from Brora but you donrsquot really hear of a Championship team getting beaten by a Highland League or a Lowland League team ever.ldquoIt was a shock, it was a big shock, but fair play to them.ldquoWhat an achievement it is and it is an amazing challenge to overcome.ldquoYou cannot take anything away from them.Stranraer have enjoyed an impressive start to the campaign, with just one defeat since the beginning of November, as they look toto League One.Paton, who now lives in Bothwell, South Lanarkshire, has been at the heart of that form, scoring eight goals in all competitions, with strikes against Spartans and a last-minute penalty winner against Kelty Hearts in the previous round.He has also found the net for Gala Fairydean Rovers, while on loan from Hibs, and for East Kilbride in the competition last year.Now, attention has turned to the trip to Brora and Paton said: ldquoTherersquos nothing better in the world than scoring. Any forward player will tell you that. If you have a terrible game and score a goal or play fantastic and not score ndash you are judged on your goals as a forward.ldquoHopefully, I will get another goal but I need to make sure I am in the team. I would love another goal and I love the Scottish Cup. I loved it with East Kilbride and Gala Fairydean Rovers ndash it is great and you love those big moments in competitions.Paton moved from Dublin to East Lothian after signing for Hibs around his th birthday.He lived with Helen Leslie and her two sons, Darren and Jonathan, off Tranentrsquos Waterloo Road and attended Ross High School, where he studied physical education, English and sports leadership.The striker was quick to praise both the family and the school for helping him develop. He said: ldquoThey took me in asI was part of their family.ldquoThey were absolutely fantastic to me and made me feel so welcome.ldquoI went for dinner with them and they were brilliant.ldquoIn my first year, I spoke to Sean McPartlin, education and welfare officer, and he askedI wanted to do something. I agreed to it and they said I would train some days.ldquoIt is the best thing I ever did.That saw Paton ide his time between attending school and training at Hibernian Training Centre at East Mains on the outskirts of Ormiston.The -year-old spent two years at the secondary school and told Courier Sport how much he enjoyed the experience. He added: ldquoIt was brilliant ndash the best thing I ever did, honestly.ldquoI was not too keen going to school at that age with football andI had not then I would not have made many friends. The amount of people I met through school was unbelievable.Paul Reynolds, headteacher of the Tranent secondary school, said: ldquoNot only was Ruari a standout footballer, he was a true gentleman.ldquoHe was always extremely polite and his positive attitude was infectious. I have rarely met someone so filled with optimism.ldquoWith his lsquogo get lsquoemrsquo attitude, he settled into Ross High School very quickly and it was a pleasure to have him here. Irsquom delighted to hear that he is still playing and wish him all the very best.

title: plans-second-substation-former-cockenzie-power-station-site-lodged-council
story: The latest planning application, from Seagreen Wind Energy, shows a substation built on top of a former gasholder site stretching across paths which the firm admits may have to be erted.Seagreen sparked local concern when its initial consultation appeared to put the entire Greenhills in its proposed site.However, the plans now lodged with the council show the substation across the road from the former Cockenzie Power Stationrsquos main footprint on an old gasworks area now being used for a temporary car wash business.Acknowledging concerns raised by community councils over the loss of green space, Seagreenrsquos application says: ldquoAs far as possible, the proposed substationwill be sited to avoid any areas of habitat value. Where not possible, we confirm that any potential loss of woodland or scrub would be compensated for by post-construction landscape planting.And they added that any loss of existing footpaths was still to be discussedto agree how to mitigate it, adding: ldquoThis will likely involve a ersion to the existing footpath. If this is required, we will seek to minimise theof this ersion as far as possible.Seagreen currently has apoundbn offshore wind farm development under construction after it was granted exclusiverights for the Firth of Forth Zone of the UKrsquos Round  offshore wind farm development programme.Phase One within the zone includes the development of two offshore wind farms ndash Seagreen Alpha and Seagreen Bravo ndash located more than km from the Angus coastline.Work is already under way to bring the energy online at a number of sites, with Cockenzie the latest to be put forward.The former Cockenzie Power Station site was bought by East Lothian Council from ScottishPower after the stationrsquos iconic chimneys were demolished.It has been marketed by the local authority for projects, with a visionary masterplan setting out a wide range of employment, energy and recreational uses for the large -hectare site and surrounding area.To date, a substation which will bring energy onshore for Inch Cape Offshore Ltd is the only proposal given planning permissionfor the site.Seagreenrsquos proposals cover a nearby area of land outwith the power station footprint itself, including a beach car park next to it, where underground cables would be brought on land, under the main road and into the National Grid inshore.The proposal includes an onshore substation, underground electricity cables and ldquotemporary and permanent infrastructure to export electricity.

title: plea-save-ground-floor-closed-haddington-pub-keep-business-use
story: Plans were revealed last month to transform the three-storey Gardeners Arms in the centre of Haddington.The historic venue, on the townrsquos Kilpair Street, dates back hundreds of years, with The Fraternity of Gardeners of East Lothian once based in the town.They purchased a property which contained an inn on the corner of Market Street.However, last orders may have been called at the pub, which has not been open for about three years.Flats would be created on each floor of the building under DSI Properties Ltdrsquos plans.Haddingtonrsquos community council did not object to the proposals but felt that the plans could be altered to keep the ground floor available for business use.The proposals suggest the insignia painted on the front of the building would be retained, something which was welcomed by the group.Paul Darling, one of the community councilrsquos planning liaison officers, said: ldquoIrsquom not averse to two flats but would quite like to see the bottom house kept for retail, personally.That view was backed by colleagues Pat Lemmon and Graham Samuel during the virtual meeting.The discussions came after it was highlighted that a number of businesses had moved into neighbouring High Street in recent months, despite the challenges brought by the coronavirus pandemic and lockdown restrictions.Chris McEwan, chairman of the community council, said: ldquoI quite agree with what is being said.ldquoWe have got businesses coming into the town and there have been three opening in recent months, even during the year we have had.ldquoKeeping another retail opportunity there, especially in that part of town, is a good idea.Community councils are given the opportunity to provide their views on any planning application.East Lothian Councilrsquos planning department aims to make a decision on the application by the end of the month.The Haddington group agreed to write to East Lothian Council about the proposals, with community councillor John Hamilton suggesting it was ldquoa preference rather than an insistence that the business unit on the ground floor remain in place.A supporting statement included within the planning application highlights the dficulties facing pubs and the lack of apparent interest in someone taking over the Gardeners.It reads: ldquoThe property was sold recently to our client.ldquoIt had ceased to operate as a public house almost three years ago and had been marketed for sale without interest.ldquoThe climate in that market has not been good for some time and will become even more dficult following the current Covid outbreakand the economic fallout from this.ldquoIt is clear that an alternative use for the property needs to be foundit is not to fall into disrepair.ldquoWith this in mind, our clients opted for residential use.ldquoMore and more properties in town and city centres are being given up to residential use in an attempt to bring le back to them and help sustain existing business outlets which have managed to keep trading.

title: musician-records-sounds-north-berwick-new-album-series-depicting-seven-continents
story: Ted White, who was brought up on Cromwell Road, where parents Sally and Andrew still live, was approached by music distribution service Platoon to co-ordinate field recordings he had gathered around the world over several years and release them via Apple last month.Each of the seven albums is dedicated to a dferent continent, and the sounds of North Berwickrsquos beaches and harbour feature on the Europe: Earth Sounds album.Ted, , said: ldquoI travel a lot, recording sounds around the world, and Platoon and I collectively came up with the concept of collating my recordings of the past seven years into continents of the world.ldquoI did a bit more travelling to record the bits I didnrsquot have.A former student at Loretto now splitting his time between Liverpool and London, Ted came back to North Berwick to capture the seaside townrsquos night-time atmosphere.He said: ldquoI grew up there so I knew where I could get good sounds without the noise pollution that you get in London.ldquoI recorded lots of midnight sounds on the beaches. Itrsquos very, very quiet where the golf course practice range is, so I went down there.ldquoAnd also the harbour, for lots of the clinking and clanking of sails and at the jetty down by the harbour when the tide was at its highest. I put a load of microphones and left them there as well.With more than  hoursrsquo worth of sounds, Ted used recordings he had made in erse places, including the Amazon rainforest, Rajasthan in India, and Norway.For those places he was unable to get to, such as Antarctica, Ted recreated the noises he imagined would be heard using his own instruments and accessories. For Antarctica, he recorded harsh winds and tents flapping, ice chunks moving around a bath, and also penguins at the zoo.But he was moved toto North Berwick last year for the Europe album.He said: ldquoItrsquos my interpretation of what I think the world sounds like some people will agree, some people wonrsquot.ldquoItrsquos my musical sound diary, so to speak and for the Europe album there were places that I felt connected to, so I recorded a lot in the Highlands, around Aberfeldy, in the winter, to get those blustery sounds, and a lot around North Berwick because thatrsquos where I grew up and, to be honest, when yoursquore trying to capture sounds itrsquos so dficult to find places which have not a lot of noise pollution, and North Berwick in the night for some reason is not that loud.The Mindfulness Nature albums can be found online at sites including Apple Music and Spoty.

title: musselburgh-churches-helping-food-donations-pandemic
story: Musselburgh Baptist Church opens its foodbank every Thursday morning between am and noon, while St Andrewrsquos High Church members have been helping out East Lothian Foodbank.Ross McNab, assistant pastor at the baptist church, said it was ldquoamazing that the congregation was back together meeting in person since the end of March, adding that the church wanted to extend ldquoa warm welcome to our wider community to come join us.He added: ldquoWe are meeting together every Sunday and currently hold three services at am, .am and noon. Each service lasts approximately one hour and contains a mixture of music, teaching and prayer.ldquoTo help us follow current guidelines and maintain a safe environment, booking is required. To book a seat, please get in touch via info@musselburghbaptist.org or message us through our Facebook page , where we also livestream our .am service.The Rev Dr Leslie Milton, minister at St Andrewrsquos High Church, said: ldquoWe have had a particular focus on supporting East Lothian Foodbank throughout the pandemic and members were active in Resilient Musselburgh while it was operating.ldquoOur morning worship is at am in church and on Facebook. We hold an additional service on a Tuesday afternoon once a month for those who are unable to come out in the morning.ldquoWe have a weekly coffee morning and occasional discussion groups on Zoom. We are now livestreaming the services. We are also able through Facebook and the weekly email to include people who find it hard to get to church. The weekly email with the full service and the livestream services will continue even after all restrictions are lted.ldquoWe are surprised and delighted by the way many older people have embraced technology and social media.

story: Police highlighted the incidents in a report to Haddingtonrsquos community council on April .The first incident took place on the townrsquos Florabank Road on March , with a second vehicle stopped two days later at the townrsquos Abbotsview Junction.On both occasions, the driver was cautioned and charged and a conditional offer issued.

title: scottish-seabird-centre-host-first-ever-marine-festival
story: The conservation and education charity, which has now reopened to the public, will see its two-week Marine Fest kick off on May , with a programme of events including workshops, live science shows, rockpool rambles, bird identication walks, beach cleans, puppet shows and sand sculpting.Susan Davies, Scottish Seabird Centre chief executive, said: ldquoAs climate change warms our oceans and threatens the basis of all le, our conservation and education work is now more important than ever.ldquoThe climate crisis is one of the most challenging issues to address but there are steps everyone can take inidually, or in our communities, that can help reduce the overall pressures on our marine environment and seabirds.ldquoAt the Scottish Seabird Centre, we help people to understand some of the things they can do to address this, we explain marine science, prompt ideas and motivate people to make their own behavioural changes in response to the climate crisis.The new festival, supported by EventScotland as part of the Year of Coasts and Waters   and Scotlandrsquos Events Recovery Fund, will enable visitors to learn more about Scotlandrsquos seas and the challenges they face, especially the climate emergency.Susan added: ldquoOur Marine Fest programme of activities should provide something for members of the local community and visitors to enjoy. We would like to thank EventScotland for their support through Scotlandrsquos Year of Coasts and Waters, which has allowed us to create this new festival.Paul Bush OBE, director of events at VisitScotland, said: ldquoWe are delighted to support Marine Fest as part of the Year of Coasts and Waters  .ldquoScotland offers the perfect stage to explore our natural environment and this yearrsquos festival will combine live and digital events to showcase and celebrate the countryrsquos marine environment and wildle.The Scottish Seabird Centre is now open daily and its Marine Fest will run from May  to June .For more information, visit seabird.org

title: pictures-kiltwalkers-america-germany-help-boost-north-berwick-charity
story: On April , supporters and members of Stepping Out, based in North Berwick, took part in the virtual Kiltwalk event to raise funds for the project.The Kiltwalk sees people take part in the walking challenge and raise money for Scottish charities in the process.Due to the coronavirus pandemic, this yearrsquos event took place virtually.But it was not just in East Lothian that people were taking part.Walkers and cyclists grabbed some tartan and took part, with some even helping raise money for the charity in Germany and New York.The virtual Kiltwalk event enabled the charityrsquos members, who would not take part in a mass event, to participate, contribute and enjoy being part of the experience.There was not one set route for supporting Stepping Out, with participants instead walking ious routes according to inidual ability.Most of the East Lothian walkers followed parts of the John Muir Way.The projectrsquos community mental health team walked from North Berwick to Dunbar, a total distance of  miles.Stepping Out staff member Ann Richardson and her daughter Meg walked from Haddington to Longniddry, where they enjoyed a vegan cookie, and then travelled on to North Berwick, also a total distance of  miles.Some members took on a half-marathon distance, which saw them get the train to Longniddry and walk back to North Berwick, while others with limited mobility challenged themselves with a walk around the Lodge Grounds or the -kilometre route to the lake at the Balgone Estate, to the south of North Berwick.Not everyone walked during the challenge, with some title: nicola-sturgeon-lockdown-update-covid-rules-set-ease
story: People in Scotland will be able to hugged loved ones again from Monday ndash subject to restrictions ndash an emotional Nicola Sturgeon has said as she confirmed further lockdown easing.These changes will include meeting up to six people from three households socialising indoors, restaurants, cafeacutes, pubs and bars openingindoors until :, and cinemas, theatres, comedy clubs, amusement arcades and bingo halls reopening and, quarantine-free international travel.It comes after the Covid- alert level in the UK was downgraded from Level  to Level  after a "consistent"fall in cases, hospital admissions and deaths.The four chief medical officers of the UK put it downto the success of the vaccination programme and social distancing restrictions.Heres what you need to know:The First Minister confirmed that the majority of Scotland will move to Level  lockdown from May .Moray will stay in Level and the Scottish Islands will move to Level  from Monday.These changes will include, but are not limited to, being able to meet inside a home, drinking alcohol inside a pub or restaurant, the reintroduction of adult contact sports and meeting eight peoplefrom eight households outdoors.Household changesThe maximum number of people who can meet indoors socially ina homeis six people which can be from three households, including for overnight stays.Hugs are back!Nicola Sturgeon has confirmed that hugs will be allowed indoors in Scotland.The First Minister said: "From Monday,you are meeting friends and family, within the permitted limits of course, either indoors in a private dwelling or in your garden, our guidance will say that it is no longer necessary to maintain physical distance."Which means - and I actually feel a bit emotional as I say this - that from Monday, as long as you stay within permitted limits, you can hug your loved ones again."I know how desperate we all are for this - and so I donrsquot intend to immediately pour cold water on it - but there are two further points I really need to make."She added: "Close physical contact does still carry risk, I have to be clear about that."Soyou have loved ones who are vulnerable for any reason, please still be careful. And limit the overall number of people that you choose to have close physical contact with."Nicola Sturgeon confirmed that Moray will not move to Level  and will stay in Level  for a "further period".The decision comes as health authorities in the area are currently dealing with "uncontrolled, sustained community transmission"of Covid-, with current restrictions failing to contain the spread.Latest statistics show Moray had . cases per , people in the seven days to May , signicantly higher than the rate in the rest of Scotland.Travel restrictions willbe brought into Moray and people should only enter there for essential purposes only.Ms Sturgeon said: "In recent days, as you will have seen, Moray has been experiencing a high and increasing number of cases with a small associated increase in hospital admissions."Indeed, public health experts consider that Moray is currently experiencing widespread community transmission."She added: "It is therefore highly probable that Moray will stay at level  for a further period."It is also important that we take precautions to reduce the risk of the transmission of Covid spreading from Moray to other parts of Scotland, as restrictions ease where.""SoMoray does stay in level  - which will be finally decided at the end of the week - we will also reimpose travel restrictions for a hopefully short period.This will mean that travel in and out of Moray will be limited to permitted purposes only."Islands changesMany islands in Scotland will move to Level  due to low case numbers.Nicola Sturgeon said:"For our island communities, the situation is dferent and much more positive."Case numbers have consistently been at very low levels for some time now."Many islands also now have very good vaccination coverage, and lateral flow tests are available for all people travelling to the islands from other parts of Scotland."For those reasons, we have decided that it is possible to ease restrictions more quickly for communities in the Western Isles, Shetland and Orkney for all islands in Highland, except Skye, given its fixed link and for the Inner Hebrides islands in Argyll - including Islay, Jura and Mull."All of these areas will move directly to level  from Monday, rather than to level ."International TravelPeople in Scotland will be able to travel to some foreign destinations without the need to quarantine on their .It will be part of a traffic lights system, similar to that in England, and will come into effect on May .Countries are to be classied as green, amber and red and a review will take place every four weeks.Nicola Sturgeon said: "At the outset, let me be very clear that we still intend to be highly cautious on international travel - given the risk of new iants - but we consider that the situation now allows us to begin a careful move away from blanket restrictions on non-essential travel."From Monday, we will move to a traffic light system, informed by risk assessments prepared by the Joint Biosecurity Centre. These assessments will be based on the state of the pandemic in each country across the world - including the presence of iants of concern."These green countries include:The First Minister was unable to update on the latest Covid numbers due to "IT issues".Nicola Sturgeon said:"I hope that will be resolved soon, and I can assure you that all of todays figures will be published just as quickly as possible."Youll be able to access them when theyre published on the Scottish Government website."

title: spectators-welcomed-back-musselburgh-racecourse-later-month
story: In a carefully managed event, the East Lothian track will admit  racing fans in the first steps towards lting Covid- restrictions and resuming normal racing.The racecourse has worked closely with the East Lothian Safety Advisory Group to establishing a raceday protocol, which can be amended as further restrictions are relaxed in the weeks ahead.At the afternoon meeting on May , alcohol and food can only be ordered and must be consumed at tables in a designated picnic area, while a two-metre distancing rule will be enforced throughout the course.The racecourse has also confirmed that its popular Stobo Castle Ladies Day has been moved from August  to Friday, August , to maximise the enhanced safety benefits from the Governmentrsquos objective of having every adult vaccinated by the end of July.A crowd limit for what is traditionally a sell-out event will be set once it becomes clear what restrictions, , any might be in place in August.Bill Farnsworth, Musselburgh Racecourse general manager, said: ldquoIt has been a very challenging year for Musselburgh and all Scottish racecourses, and while our instinct is to welcome back as many racing fans as possible, we are erring on the side of caution by opting to admit only  visitors are our next meeting.ldquoThe measures we have put in place underline that the safety of our guests, racing industry personnel and our staff must come first, but we will use the meeting on May  as a template for going forward.ldquoNo doubt we will learn what works best for hosting a race day for the general public against the backdrop of Covid- restrictions."We are confident we can offer an entertaining afternoon of live sport with ample space around the course to allow visitors to socially distance.Mr Farnworth stressed that no bars or restaurants would be open and that food and alcohol would only be served at a designated seated picnic area. Visitors will not be allowed to enter the grounds with their own picnics.He added: ldquoMoving Stobo Castle Ladies Day to August  is simply to give us the best chance of hosting our most popular race meeting in a more relaxed environment, and given that most people should by then have received their vaccinations, this should add an extra layer of comfort for racegoers.Guests who have already booked Ladies Day admission tickets for August  have been informed of the change of date and been issued refunds, and they will prioritised when rebooking for the August  event.In June, Musselburgh hosts three racedays, including The Edinburgh Cup Raceday on Saturday, June , two afternoon meetings in July, and in August a further four meetings, including Stobo Castle Ladies Day. The racecourse will release details for these fixture as the relaxation of Covid regulations develops.Tickets for the race meetings on May  and June  go on sale on Thursday at am and are expected to sell out quickly.For a full fixture list and to book tickets, visit musselburgh-racecourse

title: covid-recovery-first-focus-says-new-east-lothian-msp-paul-mclennan
story: Paul McLennan won the county seat for the SNP as he defeated Labourrsquos Martin Whitfield, the Conservativesrsquo Craig Hoy ndash both of whom are now South Scotland MSPs ndash and Euan Davidson of the Liberal Democrats.MSPs are sworn in at the Scottish Parliament today , with Mr McLennan ndash who has risen through the ranks from community councillor in Dunbar to former East Lothian Council leader to MSP ndash keen to look to the future.Speaking on Tuesday morning, Mr McLennan, who is also a ward councillor for Dunbar and East Linton, said: ldquoI think for me, the whole focus for the next wee while is going to be Covid recovery.ldquoThere are three main areas for me, including economic recovery.ldquoThat has been good so far and I have got a real feel for where businesses are.ldquoI chaired the town centre group on the council and we have a meeting where we talk about tourism, the town centre and the general economic position. We do that every week and that is the key thing now: getting businesses open.ldquoTourism is a major part of that and there will be another announcement hopefully to see more reopening.ldquoWe have just got to try to support tourism, leisure, hospitality, town centres and the broader economic recovery.Mr McLennan, who is exploring how to donate his councillor salary to a local charity while an MSP, has already been in discussions with Lesley Brown, executive director of education and childrenrsquos services at East Lothian Council, about the educational recovery in the wake of the pandemic.He stressed that it was not just about the next six months or even a year but looking beyond that.Similarly, Mr McLennan, who lives in Dunbar with we Sharron, was keen to work with the NHS in its recovery.Labour had held the East Lothian seat since the Scottish Parliament was formed in , with John Home Robertson and then Iain Gray representing the county for more than  years.However, , people voted for Mr McLennan last Thursday, with Mr Whitfield finishing in second spot on ,.The victor told the Courier his phone had ldquonever stopped ringing with people congratulating him ahead of his first trip to Holyrood as a newly elected MSP.He said: ldquoIt felt a bit surreal but the overriding thing is it is incredibly humbling just thinking about the amount of support.ldquoI am really determined now with people putting faith in myself and the SNP it is up to me now to go and repay that faith.ldquoI am very proud of what we achieved and really looking forward to getting into the business of parliament.The election count was held on Friday at Meadowmill Sports Centre, near Tranent, with coronavirus restrictions in place.Mr McLennan, who plans to have a constituency office set up this summer, said he and the party were ldquocautiously optimistic as the day wore on but it was too close to call as to who would come out on top.The four candidates were then invited into a room and told the result before it was made public.Mr McLennan, who has lived in Dunbar all his le and previously worked with the Bank of Scotland on the townrsquos High Street, took time to thank those who had helped him during the campaign but also singled out someone who could not be there, his dad Jim, who died two years ago.He said: ldquoI could not drive until I was about  for ious reasons.ldquoMy dad used to drive me to surgeries and to meetings sometimes.ldquoHe died from dementia two years ago and in his last few years he could hardly talk but I remember he said: lsquoThatrsquos my son, he is a councillor.rsquoldquoWhen I was elected to East Lothian Council in , it meant so much to him and he was one of the first thoughts I had on Friday.ldquoI was thinking about my dad andhe had been there.Mr McLennan, who previously served on Dunbar Community Council, became a councillor in  when he was elected as one of three members of the Dunbar and East Linton ward.The father-of-two, whose son Scott is a coach at Heart of Midlothian FC and daughter Kirsty works with Musselburgh catering and events firm Hickory, is now looking forward to working alongside both Mr Whitfield, who was previously East Lothian MP from  to , and Craig Hoy, who is a councillor, representing the Haddington and Lammermuir ward.Mr McLennan, who has vowed to stay on as a councillor until next yearrsquos local authority elections, said: ldquoI think voters had a really good choice of experienced candidates ndash Martin is an ex-MP and Craig being a councillor ndash which made winning even more rewarding for myself.ldquoThere are guidelines for constituency and list MSPs and what they can do but we can work together in delivering for East Lothian.ldquoI congratulate both of them and look forward to working with them.

story: Itrsquos looking for  people to take part in a consumer taste trial where they will sample the beer.Run by the universityrsquos Scottish Centre for Food Development and Innovation, the team is recruiting  people who are already stout drinkers ndash those who enjoy the occasional pint of Guinness, Belhaven Black or Murphyrsquos ndash as well as  who have not drunk stout before but are keen to try it.Recruitment for tasters starts now, with the trial to begin later this month.Each participant who completes tastings and provides the necessary feedback will be rewarded with a pound John Lewis or Amazon voucher as a thank you for taking part.Participants, ideally from Edinburgh and the Lothians, will be asked to pick up samples from the university and will be given two sample stout recipes to taste at home. They will need to complete an online questionnaire to provide feedback and highlight their preferred sample. Access to the internet is essential and the feedback process is believed to take about - minutes to complete.Catriona Liddle, who heads up the Scottish Centre for Food Development and Innovation, is running the trial.She said: ldquoOur consumer tasting  are extremely popular with foodies and people from the local community who enjoy sampling and talking about food and drink. Itrsquos open to people who are already part of our existing consumer , but itrsquos also an opportunity for new people who might like to get involved in further food and drink tasting .ldquoWe normally have multiple sessions running on campus each week across all food types. The only consideration is that sadly we cannot accept any applications from those with food allergies or food restrictions.ldquoThe samples on this trial will be blind tested, so participants wonrsquot know which type of stout they are tasting, and we will be using the results to help create Scotlandrsquos favourite stout.Email the food team at consumer@qmu.ac.uk to apply.Participants must be aged  and over.

story: A holiday let cottage is already in place above Canty Bay, to the east of the town, but a developer has applied to East Lothian Council for planning permission for a new building on the site to replace the existing property.A design statement for Ryan Lothian, who is behind the proposals, said: ldquoThe proposal explores the replacement of an existing dwelling in Canty Bay which, despite regular maintenance over the last  years, has reached the end of its natural lespan and is no longer habitable.Earlier this year, a condition survey carried out at the cottage found it ldquoin a poor condition with penetrative damp and decaying timbers.The new cottage would replace the existing property, which dates back to before the Second World War.The design statement continued: ldquoThe existing two-bedroom cottage is deemed uninhabitable and is in a severely deteriorating condition.ldquoTherefore the proposal is to replace the existing cottage with a contemporary dwelling that nestles into the surrounding landscape.ldquoThe proposed replacement dwelling is of a similar size, scale and massing to the existing cottage and responds positively to the local context in order to protect and enhance the coastal character and quality of landscape.

title: scotland-home-year-inside-katie-spiers-home
story: ldquoI didnrsquot really have TV in my mind, says Spiers, , ldquoit wasnrsquot something I thought I would ever do. Irsquove always been happy with my online job and content creation, but when I went for a meeting with the team, I just loved them ndash they were so passionate about the show, and I just thought lsquookay, letrsquos try it out!rsquoThe popular home show continues to attract a strong following in its third series,Spiers believes demand will be at an all-time high. ldquoI think itrsquos a really great programme to go on after so long in lockdown, she highlights.ldquoWhen everyonersquos been looking at the same four walls for the last year, lots of people have big plans for what theyrsquore going to do with their homes, and for when they can have tradesmen back into the house, so I think watching an interiors show is going to be inspiring for people hellip a welcome bit of voyeurism.Despite the fluctuating restrictions of the pandemic last year, the crew, alongside Spiersrsquos fellow judges interior designer Anna Campbell-Jones and architect Michael Angus, were able to film series three last September.ldquoI would not recommend filming during a pandemic, laughs Spiers. ldquoWe would do Covid tests every couple of days, get temperature checks twice a day ndash we constantly had thermometers hanging out of our mouths.ldquoWe were really lucky we could get out to film, and it was great to see more of Scotland.Originally from New Zealand, Spiers considers herself an honorary Scot since moving here as a child. The content creator has a weighty , followers on Instagram, many of whom were gained over the last year alone. ldquoMy following grew massively during the pandemic, she explains, ldquowhereas it hadnrsquot grown that much in the last couple of years.One of the main reasons for this influx is Spiersrsquos dreamy, aesthetically pleasing interiors.ldquoI would think my niche, or my USP, is probably that I live quite a simple le ndash I view my content as being attainable but slightly aspirational.ldquoMy husband and I live in a three-bedroom tenement flat in the southside of Glasgow ndash itrsquos far from a mansion, but it has period detailing and wersquove done a lot of work to make it our own and inject our personality into it. Itrsquos also a style that is easy to replicate.ldquoIrsquom quite inspired by Southern Calornian style ndash lots of wood and greenery, earthy tones, and textures. I bring a lot of that into my home, I love rattan and a bit of s style. I think Irsquove created quite a colourful home that brings me a lot of joy.So, after being able to add TV presenter to her ever-growing CV, whatrsquos next for Spiers  ldquoWriting is my passion, she emphasises. ldquoI would love to write a book one day, a collection of essays, I think ndash thatrsquos something Irsquove always been leading up to. Although everybody always wants me to do an interiors book!Kate shares her top tips to freshen up your home for springThere is no better time to refresh your home than the start of a new season, and the arrival of spring definitely brings with it a chance to declutter and revive your space. So, throw open your windows, stock up on blossom-scented cleaning supplies and follow my steps for freshening up your home for spring hellipDeep clean and declutter:Spring is the perfect time to assess your home and see what you can donate or throw out. Irsquove made multiple trips to the recycling centre lately and it really has made a dference to my home ndash I know Irsquoll never be a minimalist, but it feels calming to have a little less clutter at least.Set aside an hour or so once a week to clear out your wardrobe, kitchencabinets and hallway cupboards.Reorganise sideboards and shelves, and get rid of anything you havenrsquot used or worn in a while ndash be ruthless! Then give everything a once-over as you go ndash spring cleaning is good for the soul.Have a room refresh: Changing the layout of a room and giving your home a bit of a rejig does wonders for making the space feel like new. Once or twice a year Irsquoll consider how I can switch up my spaces. Irsquoll move furniture, swap out soft furnishings, relocate the sofa to another position or change our spare room completely. Irsquoll even rework the gallery walls and artwork around my home. Itrsquos like redecorating but without spending a penny.Bring the outdoors: in Stock up on tulips, daffodils and peonies, and place bouquets around your home ndash on mantelpieces, sideboards, kitchen worktops and coffee tables. Irsquom a big fan ofgreenery in the home too ndash plants like Pothos, Monstera deliciosa and ZZ plants are so easy to take care of and really breathe a bit of le into a room. Irsquom all about the indoor jungle, so go wild with blooms and plants and your home will feel bright and breezy in no time.Consider a lick of paint: With so many fun paint brands launching lately , itrsquos easier than ever to add colour to your le. Opt for a fresh eucalyptus green to revive a bathroom, or pick a played-down pink for warmth. Go wild with it ndash paint a feature wall in your living room or section off a room with a dado rail and paint the lower section a bright shade. Bold colours never go out of style.www.katelavie

title: new-gps-nurses-call-handlers-join-riverside-medical-practice-musselburgh
story: Two new GPs, two nurse practitioners and two new call handlers have taken up jobs at the surgery since the start of the year, with a further GP due to arrive in the summer and two GPs due tofrom maternity leave.Recruitment for one more GP is ongoing, with a fresh recruitment push due to launch shortly to coincide with new GPs entering the workplace as their training comes to an end.Dr Richard Kitto, a long-standing doctor at the practice, has been made a GP partner.The Courier has previously reported that the practice has come under fire from frustrated patients who have complained about dficulties contacting it to secure appointments.Commenting on the recruitment drive, Dr Richard Fairclough, GP partner, said: ldquoWe must stress to all of our patients and stakeholders in the local community that this remains an exceptionally busy time for general practices all over the country. Our successful recruitment is good news but wersquore now ndash with the exception of one GP, a nurse practitioner and the further call handlers ndash at the limit of the number of people we can employ at the practice yet we estimate that demand for appointments will still outweigh our capacity to provide them.He explained: ldquoWe must therefore continue to stress the urgent need for the full implementation of the  GMS Contract, which lays out the ious types of care due to be removed from the remit of general practice, in order to allow GPs to provide the expert medical care to the local community that we so desperately want to be able to do.He added: ldquoThis is widely recognised to be a challenging time to recruit GPs, with more GPs leaving the Scottish workforce each year than new GPs entering it.ldquoSo given this, wersquore especially delighted to welcome our two new GPs to the practice. Dr Maeve Chestnutt joined us from the Forth Valley Practice in March after relocating to East Lothian and Dr Michael Slowey has joined us last week from a practice in Sussex after locuming with us for a short time.He continued: ldquoWersquod also like to extend warm congratulations to Dr Kitto, who joins myself, Dr Cameron and Dr Stenke as a GP partner.Dr Fairclough said: ldquoTheirs arenrsquot the only new faces at the practice this year. Senior nurse practitioner Chris Gent has joined us as clinical manager from NHS , bringing his considerable clinical and operational experience to Riverside, along with nurse practitioner Sarah Miller.ldquoFinally, wersquore so pleased to welcome a further two new call handlers to our reception team, with more to follow shortly. Being a GP receptionist is such a challenging role, requiring a deep knowledge of how the surgery works, as well as calmness under pressure, and outstanding customer service skills. We know our two new recruits are going to make a great contribution to our now -strong reception team.
